briefOverview: A series of temple visions report the Lord’s acceptance of the house and the conferral of priesthood keys by Moses, Elias, and Elijah. These keys relate to gathering Israel, extending Abrahamic blessings, and preparing for the Lord’s coming.
summary: The narrators see the Lord standing upon the pulpit’s breastwork, radiant and majestic, declaring himself as Jehovah, the first and the last, their advocate, and pronouncing them clean. He accepts the house built to his name, promises to manifest himself there if his people keep the commandments, and foretells joy, blessings, an endowment, and renown spreading to foreign lands. After this vision closes, Moses appears and confers the keys for the gathering of Israel and leading the ten tribes from the land of the north. Then Elias appears and commits the dispensation of the gospel of Abraham, declaring that in them and their seed all generations shall be blessed. Finally, Elijah appears, affirming Malachi’s prophecy about turning the hearts of fathers and children before the great and dreadful day of the Lord, and he commits the keys of this dispensation, indicating that the day is near.
externalContext: This vision is historically situated in early Latter-day Saint history at the Kirtland Temple in Ohio, shortly after its dedication in March 1836, with contemporary accounts naming Joseph Smith and Oliver Cowdery as the recipients. Early Latter-day Saint usage of “endowment” at Kirtland involved washings, anointings, instruction, and promised spiritual empowerment rather than later standardized temple rites. Latter-day Saints interpret the conferral of “keys” as authoritative rights to direct aspects of God’s work, such as missionary gathering and temple ordinances. Many Latter-day Saint sources also note that April 3, 1836, the reported date of this vision, coincided with Passover, a time in Jewish tradition associated with Elijah’s expected return.
externalReferences: The description of the Lord—eyes as a flame, countenance brighter than the sun, voice like many waters, identifying himself as “the first and the last”—echoes Revelation 1:14–18 and related passages that depict the glorified Christ, and resonates with 1 John 2:1 regarding Christ as “advocate.” Elijah’s appearance explicitly fulfills Malachi 4:5–6, and his earlier translation is narrated in 2 Kings 2:11. The “gospel of Abraham” and the promise that “in [their] seed all generations…be blessed” reflect Genesis 12:3; 22:18 and are interpreted in the New Testament in Galatians 3:8; the gathering from the “land of the north” aligns with prophecies such as Jeremiah 31:8 and Isaiah 11:12.
practicalQuestions: What does it look like, in practice, to keep the Lord’s commandments so that sacred spaces are not polluted?
How can I personally share in the promised rejoicing by participating in temple worship and its associated blessings?
In what concrete ways can I contribute to the gathering of Israel today?
How can I turn my heart toward my ancestors and my posterity in ways that are faithful and actionable?
How should the nearness of the Lord’s day influence the priorities and tone of my discipleship?
uncertainAreas: The identity of “Elias” (v. 12) is not clarified in the text and is interpreted variously in Latter-day Saint discourse. The exact scope of the “endowment” promised (v. 9) and how it relates to later temple practices is not specified. The phrase “leading of the ten tribes from the land of the north” (v. 11) leaves open questions about timing, location, and manner. The recipients are not named within the chapter, though historical context identifies them; the text itself uses “us,” leaving some readerly ambiguity without external sources.
